prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB1_ToO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of GRB, preferentially in the night following the trigger, otherwise nominally within the advertised 48 hrs turn-around time. Obtain 100 GHz total flux for a GRB afterglow (point source).

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
The time of the first visit will be determined by triggering (this is a ToO proposal) and the advertised 48 h turn-around time. We understand that this will be done on a best-effort basis and fully accept the risk of not getting an observation - we will not make the ALMA team responsible if this rapid turn-around cannot be met!
The second epoch should be done within 6--24 hrs after the first, and another 2 epochs at logarithmic spacing (2+-1 days and 4+-2 days after the previous, respectively). We therefore request 4 epochs (=triggers) per GRB, for each of 3 GRBs to be triggered.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are interested primarily in continuum emission. For the add-on science case of detecting CO emission in absorption against the GRB afterglow, the standard spectral resolution is per IF band is fully sufficient.

GRB afterglows are point sources. The size of the surrounding field which is being imaged is irrelevant - we therefore can accept every antenna configuration. Host galaxies are typically even fainter - if they are detected, they have at maximum 3 arcsec diameter, and their emission will be subtracted based on the multiple visits of the host+afterglow system, the total flux of which is expected to change.

The source strength is not accurately predictable. We therefore adopt a sensitivity of 20 microJy per trigger which provides a rms a factor 5 lower than the deepest upper limit achieved so far for an afterglow 2 days after the GRB. For brighter emission, we gain important temporal resolution which will be correlated with the 2min time resolution of the optical/NIR imaging.

We are happy with the standard setting for band 3. Band 3 has been chosen to be as independent as possible from weather conditions (being a target-of-opportunity observation), and at the same time provide lever arm to ATCA (radio) and near-infrared (GROND).

GRB afterglows fade within days (X-rays) to weeks (mm, radio). The scientific goals of this proposal require broad-band coverage, thus the ALMA observations should be done in the same time window as the X-ray, optical/NIR and radio observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Jet emission is ubiquitous in astrophysical sources, yet the jet launching mechanism is widely debated, with different models giving rise to different degrees of magnetization, outflow geometries and emission profiles. The jets in gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are unique phenomena to observationally constrain some of these aspects: they are bright, observable over a wide range of wavebands, and evolve on short timescales. We propose multi-epoch ToO ALMA observations of three GRB afterglows to constrain the peak of the synchrotron emission spectrum. Combined with public X-ray data from Swift, our proprietary and guaranteed optical/NIR (GROND) and radio (ATCA) data, the multi-epoch spectral energy distribution (SED) from 5 GHz to 10 keV will allow us to trace the spectral characteristics from different parts of the jet, compare the observed SED evolution to theoretical predictions (e.g. the GRB `fireball' scenario, single and multi-component jet outflows, limb-brightened or -darkend jet profile) and to measure precisely the energy partition between electrons and magnetic field.
